com.esri.mo2.src.sys
Class ContentUtility

java.lang.Object
  |
  +--com.esri.mo2.src.sys.ContentUtility
public class ContentUtility
extends Object

Various utilities for defining and accessing Content via an "access string". Typically, this is used by design-time components that wish to specify a particular Content using a single String property. At design-time, a property editor can provide a gui for end users to populate this string.

Nested Class Summary

Method Detail

getContentAccess

public static String getContentAccess(Content content,
                                      char separator)
                               throws Exception
provides a String that uniquely defines access to the given Content. The String contains 3 sub-strings separated using the given separator as follows:
     class name of the Connection
       separator
     the Content's path
       separator
     the connection parameters for the Connection

Parameters:
content - the Content to be accessed
separator - a character used to separate 3 Strings
Returns:
the access string
Throws:
IllegalArgumentException - if content is null, or if content has no connection
ContentUtility.InvalidAccessStringException - other exceptions may be thrown if the content's connection cannot be instantiated

                               throws Exception

Parameters:

Returns:
the access string
Throws:
ContentUtility.InvalidAccessStringException - other exceptions may be thrown if the content's connection cannot be instantiated

findContentType

public static int findContentType(String type,
                                  String[] availableTypes)
searches for the given type among an array of "available" content types, using the strategy outlined in the javadoc for the Content interface, and returns an index into the array of available types if it is found, or -1 if not found.

Parameters:
type - the type to be searched for
availableTypes - the array of available types
Returns:
the index of the type among the available types, or -1 == not found
See Also:

IOException
See Also:
traverse(Folder,ContentVisitor,boolean,boolean)

traverse

public static void traverse(Folder root,
                            ContentVisitor visitor,
                            boolean order,
                            boolean includeRoot)
                     throws IOException
traverse the given Folder tree and visit it in either the forward or reverse order. This method allows you to choose to visit the root node or not.

Parameters:
visitor - the object that will be visiting each Content in the root Folder
order - true == forward (same as regular traverse), false == reverse order
includeRoot - true == the search begins by visiting the root Folder first, false == the children of root are visited first
Throws:
RuntimeException - may be thrown by the ContentVisitor in order to quickly terminate the traversal - it is calling code's responsibility to trap this exception, traverse does not catch it
IOException
See Also:
ContentVisitor

getRootFolder

public static Folder getRootFolder(Content content)
finds the root "ancestor" folder of the given Content that has the same Connection as the content. If content is (itself) a root folder, then it will be returned. If content has no parent and is a Folder, then it will be returned, otherwise null;

Returns:
the root folder, or null == this Content has no parent folder, or it is not part of a folder tree managed by a Source
Throws:
NullPointerException - if content is null

getContentForPath

public static Content getContentForPath(Folder folder,
                                        String path)
                                 throws IOException
traverses the given Folder and tries to find a Content that matches the given path. The path may be a "relative" or "absolute" - relative means that the path String does not begin with a separator character (either a "/" or "\"), absolute means that it does begin with a separator. If the path is relative, then this method tries to locate the required Content by first searching the children of the given folder. If the path is absolute, this method first searches the root Folder of the Source that created the given folder.

A path is considered to consist of Content names separated by a separator character which can either be "\" or "/" - either can be used interchangeably. There is no problem if a content name contains a separator character - there is no need to use an escape character in the path, for example, suppose a content within the path contains the name "http://server/" then the path "Internet Servers/http://gumnut/" will match a root Folder having name "Internet Servers" that contains the above content. The traversal is performed by comparing the beginning of the path with the root's Content name together with initial (optional) separator character.

A special case exists, whereby if path is null or is the empty string, then the folder itself is returned

Parameters:
folder - the Folder where path search will begin
path - the path to be searched
Returns:
the content found, or null if no content was found matching the given path
Throws:
IOException - if any problem accessing children or sub-children of folder
NullPointerException - if folder is null
